item.title: Assassin‚Äôs Creed Vets Who Led Black Flag And Origins Now In Charge Of Series
item.content:encoded:
Four months after the former head of Assassin‚Äôs Creed abruptly exited the company after allegedly being forced out, Ubisoft has tapped three veterans of the series who have worked on or led entries like Origins, Black Flag, and Revelations to take charge of the franchise inside its new Tencent-backed home at Vantage Studios.

On February 23, Ubisoft announced that Martin Schelling, Jean Guesdon, and Fran√ßois de Billy are being handed the keys to Assassin‚Äôs Creed, the French publisher‚Äôs very successful and long-running historical-based open-world stealth action franchise. These three have been connected with Assassin‚Äôs Creed for many, many years and have been involved in some of the franchise‚Äôs most popular games.

Schelling is now the head of the Assassin‚Äôs Creed brand. Ubisoft says he‚Äôll be responsible for the ‚Äúoverall strategy and long-term vision‚Äù of the series. Previously, he was Ubisoft‚Äôs chief production officer after spending 17 years in various production roles on games like Assassin‚Äôs Creed Revelations, Black Flag, Origins, and Valhalla.

Fran√ßois de Billy has been named Assassin‚Äôs Creed‚Äò ‚ÄúHead of Production Excellence,‚Äù which is a wild title to put on a resume. Fran√ßois was the production director on Assassin‚Äôs Creed Black Flag, Origins, and Valhalla. Before that, he was an associate producer on Assassin‚Äôs Creed 2 and later an executive producer of the brand. Ubisoft says that in this role he will ‚Äúoptimize processes and remove friction across complex production workflows‚Äù for the franchise. Sounds like Fran√ßois de Billy is here to help the series avoid delays.

Finally, Jean Guesdon has been named the head of content for Assassin‚Äôs Creed. He‚Äôll lead the franchise‚Äôs ‚Äúoverall creative direction‚Äù while supporting ‚Äúindividual games‚Äù and guiding the ‚Äúfuture of Assassin‚Äôs Creed.‚Äù Previously, Guesdon was the creative director on Assassin‚Äôs Creed Black Flag and Origins. Interestingly, this is essentially the same role he had at Ubisoft for many years while working on numerous titles.

He previously left Ubisoft for Behaviour Interactive back in 2023. At the time, Kotaku reported he had been leading development on a new, Minecraft-like voxel-based game called ‚ÄúRenaissance‚Äù that had yet to be announced. It was described by sources back then as being one of the more promising IPs incubating within Ubisoft at the time, with the possibility of appealing to existing fans of franchises like The Sims and Animal Crossing. But it later became a casualty of Ubisoft‚Äôs ongoing development struggles, especially around creating new IP.

Ubisoft has multiple Assassin‚Äôs Creed games in development

Schelling, de Billy, and Guesdon are now set to fill a void created by recent departures, including Marc-Alexis C√¥t√©‚Äôs break with the company in 2025 after leading Assassin‚Äôs Creed for nearly 20 years. He is suing the publisher for a forced dismissal, but Ubisoft claims he was offered a leadership role at Vantage Studios and declined it.

It is very clear that Ubisoft leadership wants to ensure that arguably its biggest, most important franchise continues to be popular and grow. In recent years, the series has struggled to tell a larger meta-narrative and ship on time. There have also been plans to intertwine future installments as part of a larger initiative, but those plans have so far seemed half-baked. 2025‚Äôs Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows was a big hit for Ubisoft, helping keep the company afloat as it limped towards a massive buyout with Tencent.

The ramifications of that deal have been lots of layoffs and cancelled projects. It has also created new co-owned subsidiaries, like Vantage Studios, that are now in charge of Ubisoft‚Äôs big franchises like Rainbow Six and Assassin‚Äôs Creed. In a recent interview with Variety, Ubisoft boss Yves Guillemot said there are multiple Assassin‚Äôs Creed games, including both multiplayer and single-player titles, currently in development. One of those is the previously reported Black Flag remake.

Pok√©mon FireRed and LeafGreen are getting Switch ports on Friday, February 27. The games aren‚Äôt readily available right now, so you‚Äôd think this announcement would have been met with universal excitement. But that wasn‚Äôt the case, as the $20 ports were deemed too expensive by some. Nevertheless, the games are topping the eShop charts already.

I gotta admit, I do find the pearl clutching about the $20 price tag a bit surprising, but in my experience, it‚Äôs impossible to have discussions about video game pricing because everyone‚Äôs perception of what a dollar is worth is so different. As the Peak devs explained, video game pricing is all weird, vibes-based psychology that some companies have figured out and others just kind of ignore. 

$20 is what you might pay for a nice meal that you‚Äôll eat and then forget about, and here it gets you a 30+-hour game. But hey, I don‚Äôt know your economic situation, so I can‚Äôt speak to what $20 in your bank account means. I‚Äôm not here to judge anyone‚Äôs perception of money, I‚Äôm more concerned about how these conversations don‚Äôt seem to take that economic disparity into account.
